channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Airstrikes in Yemen Kill Allies of Saudi-Led Coalition, Witnesses Say
item.description: The coalition killed at least 16 of its own allies, including three senior leaders, according to a fighter who was near the site of the bombing.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: Sepp Blatter Decides to Resign as FIFA President in About-Face
item.description: Four days after he was re-elected, Mr. Blatter said that he would resign his presidency of world soccer’s governing body in the wake of a corruption inquiry.
item.dc:creator: SAM BORDEN, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Sepp Blatter said FIFA was in need of "a profound overhaul."

item.title: Families Tell Lawmakers of Americans Held Hostage in Iran
item.description: The relatives of four United States citizens were pressing the Obama administration to do more to free the captives before the June 30 deadline for reaching an international agreement to limit Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Assad’s Forces May Be Aiding New ISIS Surge
item.description: Insurgents opposed to the Islamic State said the group was exploiting Syrian government airstrikes against them to seize areas near Aleppo.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Support for the European Union is Rising, Survey Suggests
item.description: A poll carried out in France, Germany, Italy, Poland, Spain and Britain found that a more resilient European economy was helping to restore faith in the bloc.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: U.N. Dismayed by Decline
item.description: The United Nations expressed alarm over the recent heavy fighting that had displaced more than 100,000 people and blocked aid deliveries to 650,000.
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Economic Scene: Climate Deal Badly Needs a Big Stick
item.description: Fruitless efforts to seriously curb greenhouse gas pollution suggest a new approach is warranted — making it costly not to join an international consortium committed to fighting climate change.
item.dc:creator: EDUARDO PORTER
item.media:description: A coal train in Printer, Ky. A proposed international tariff system would make it costly for the United States not to sign onto a reduced-emissions regime.

item.title: U.S. Envoy Held Talks With Houthi Rebels of Yemen
item.description: Anne W. Patterson, the American envoy, met last week in Oman with the Houthis to discuss violence in Yemen and the capture of several Americans.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Decline of North Sea Oil Fields Forces Political Shifts in Britain
item.description: The dropping revenue has inspired changes of tactics by British leaders as well as Scottish nationalists, who had counted on oil as an economic mainstay.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED

item.title: Open Source: Blatter’s Fall Leads to Rejoicing Online From His Critics
item.description: Sepp Blatter had the support of soccer officials but was broadly unpopular with fans of the game, so his fall was greeted with some glee.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A cameraman outside of FIFA headquarters.

item.title: News Analysis: Greece’s Alliances Fade in European Debate About Its Debt Crisis
item.description: The promise of the leftist Greek government to roll back German-led austerity policies has met an unexpectedly unified opposition.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY

item.title: World Briefing: Egypt Says It Has Arrested 2 Senior Muslim Brotherhood Leaders
item.description: The leaders, Mahmoud Ghozlan and Abdul Rahman al-Barr, were arrested this week after evading the police for nearly two years, security officials said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Boko Haram Steps Up Attacks in Northeast Nigeria, Killing Scores
item.description: The intensification of the attacks, including a suicide bombing on Tuesday, began less than a week after Nigeria’s new president vowed to crush the group.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Few Triumphs in Frantic Hunt for 430 in Yangtze River
item.description: More than a day after the Oriental Star capsized in Hubei Province, China, most of the people on board were still missing.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Rescue workers carried a body from the Oriental Star on Tuesday after it capsized in China’s Yangtze River.

item.title: World Briefing: Macedonia to Hold Early Elections Amid Political Turmoil
item.description: The agreement to hold elections in April was announced after eight hours of negotiations. The government has been under fire for months over a wiretapping scandal.
item.dc:creator: ALEKSANDAR DIMISHKOVSKI

item.title: Paris Police Clear Out Migrant Camp and Destroy Tents
item.description: The camp in north central Paris held 380 people, mostly from East Africa, who were moved to housing for asylum seekers or shelters.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: Police officers evicted African migrants living in a camp under a subway bridge in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: Anti-ISIS Coalition Makes Little Progress at Paris Meeting
item.description: The coalition of countries arrayed against the Islamic State has been hobbled by a variety of weaknesses.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Greece Challenges Creditors With New Proposal to Break Debt Impasse
item.description: Athens unveiled a plan to unlock financial aid, as creditors like the European Commission and I.M.F. were working on their own proposal.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel, third from left, and French President François Hollande, third from right, during talks at the German chancellery Monday night.

item.title: Hamas Forces Kill Leader of Islamic Splinter Group in Gaza
item.description: The fatal shooting came amid a campaign by Hamas to crack down on groups that follow the more radical Salafist stream of Islam, some of whom now adhere to the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Gunmen in Northern Afghanistan Kill 9 Local Aid Workers
item.description: The victims were two drivers, two guards and five staff members of the Czech charity People in Need, the group’s country director said.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
